title: Change in electron speed and potential

content.description: The figure shows a region of uniform electric field with magnitude <math alttext="0.2 newton per Coulomb" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, represented by the vertical electric field vectors. The dashed horizontal lines represent lines of uniform electric potential.
content.question: The electron is released from rest in the electric field. What is the speed of the electron after it has moved <math alttext="0.04 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.04</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and has the electron moved to a position of higher or lower electric potential? Gravitational effects are negligible.

choices.label: SpeedElectric Potential<math alttext="5.3 times 10 to power the 4 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mtext>.3</mtext><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>4</mtext></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>Higher

SpeedElectric Potential<math alttext="5.3 times 10 to the power 4 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mtext>.3</mtext><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>4</mtext></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>Lower

SpeedElectric Potential<math alttext="2.7 times 10 to the power 5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mtext>.7</mtext><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>5</mtext></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>Higher

SpeedElectric Potential<math alttext="2.7 times 10 to the power 5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mtext>.7</mtext><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>5</mtext></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>Lower

content.answer: SpeedElectric Potential<math alttext="5.3 times 10 to power the 4 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mtext>.3</mtext><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>4</mtext></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>Higher

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
